awd_titl_txt: CS for Insight: Disciplinary Computing Beyond CS1
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer Science's traditional role in the university setting has been to develop skilled software engineers and computing professionals.  Eclipsing, not replacing, that role is the growing need for computing expertise in non-computing disciplines.  The "CS for Insight" project at Harvey Mudd College will develop a curriculum that will serve as a bridge from a typical introductory computer science course (CS1) to discipline-specific courses in computing for many fields.  In the "CS for Insight" curriculum students will use existing computing resources, first to gain confidence in learning new interfaces, and then will apply these resources to address challenges within their discipline.  The project's broader goal will be to better understand the pathways that non-computing disciplines may follow to provide their students with the appropriate computing skills for their specific discipline.

Departments at schools across the country are exploring the many pathways for leveraging computation for their specific purposes.  Two paradigms have begun to emerge.  Some disciplines "adapt and assimilate," integrating their own computing curriculum from the very start.  Others collaborate to "factor-out-then-follow-up," choosing to build discipline-specific skills atop a computing-based CS1.  The consortium of Claremont Colleges, simultaneously widely varied and close-knit, offers a laboratory uniquely suited for comparing these paradigms head-to-head and exploring the hybrid approaches that will arise alongside.  This project will leverage this disciplinary diversity to draw a more representative cohort of students to computing.  The PI team will carefully track the demographics and computational identities of the participants to develop knowledge that can be used by others to create a model by which all disciplines can leverage computing as part their own unique culture.

por.por_cntn:
The Computing for Insight project developed, deployed, and researched computing-curriculum pathways for college and university students, with a focus on serving those who are not CS majors.

This project's Intellectual Merit draws from the observation that computing's skillsets have shown value in fields beyond CS. Through this project's courses, students of non-cs disciplines build the skillsets and mindset of "compositional computing," with the purpose of drawing insight and inquiry in their own fields. Our results (1) underscore the efficacy of framing computing as shared-with, not owned-by CS, and (2) show that compositional-computing both engages and supports non-CS students. Publications and workshops at SIGCSE, CCSC, and other venues share these courses and results.

This project's Broader Impacts come foremost from the three courses developed, piloted, and refined: a "CS2 for non-cs-majors" (hosted at Harvey Mudd College), a "Scripting-For-All" course for graduate students in the biosciences (at Keck Graduate Insitute), and a second graduate version for business and professional students (at Claremont Graduate University). Early offerings attracted only non-cs majors; from that direction, interest doubled as the curriculum has evolved through the project's span. Post-project, all three curricula continue to be offered; two are now degree requirements.

By the end of the project, interest among cs majors had grown to match that of non-cs-majors. This unexpected development suggests that "Computing for Insight" isn't cs at all... Rather, this is evidence that a subset of computing's curriculum is of value for all students, both as a medium of self-expression and a means for focused inquiry. That is, "computing for insight" and "computing for inquiry" now describe professional literacies, and they are worthwhile enough that all students should experience them.

This poses a focused, follow-on challenge, namely, to articulate those universally-valuable computing skills -- and to support today's colleges and universities in creating programs that ensure their equitable access and experience. This project provided existence-proofs for such programs; we now look forward to a Cambrian explosion of siblings and descendents in the near- and medium-term.  

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2022
Modified by: Zachary B Dodds
